ygData.subject: Re : [neat] Re: An argument in favor of developmental processes?
ygData.msgSnippet: Hi Ken, I was looking for an algorithm to develop animal morphologies (generally any kind of solid physics objects) with CPPNs. I found that writing a

Subject: Re : [neat] Re: An argument in favor of developmental processes?
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=283334584; y=BhWZqI2yxlQR1Z_mB53n_w_eZWm-Y4DMS-EtLKjTziwn-5GVKbhwLZvkCw
X-Yahoo-Profile: petar_chervenski

Hi Ken, 

I was looking for an algorithm to develop animal morphologies 
(g=
enerally any kind of solid physics objects) with CPPNs. I found that 
writi=
ng a conversion routine (CPPN snapshot -> object in world) is 
very challen=
ging and prone to many bugs and artifacts. I realized that 
object building=
 has to be done in another way - and I came up with 
this simple idea. Supp=
ose you have a set of small sticky cubes and you 
want to build a house, a =
robot or whatever your imagination has. You 
can do it like this - place on=
e cube and fix its position in space. 
See how it looks like and stick one =
more cube to it (where you want). 
See how the 2 cubes look like and then s=
tick a third one. You can 
stick the cubes along the exposed sides of the f=
ixed construction. 
Iterate this for enough time and you have the object. N=
o separate 
parts, everything rock-solid (although empty spaces can be cons=
tructed 
inside), but has internal structure with regularities, and the obj=
ect 
itself may be symmetric, segmented, or perhaps just a shitty blob. 
Th=
ese appear often. 

So let me answer to your question about what kinds of s=
hapes appear. I 
actually saw all of the biological development patterns, s=
ymmetry, 
imperfect symmetry, repetition and repetition with variation. In =

particular, the most interesting objects were created when I used 
sin(x) =
and sin(y) waves as input instead of the raw Cartesian 
coordinate frames. =
They were segmented and remarkably similar to 
biological ones. 

The imple=
mentation I uploaded currently "divides" cells, placing a 
random new cell =
in the neighborhood of the cell of consideration. A 
better solution is to =
iterate over the exposed surfaces and place new 
cells if the CPPN says so.=
 

There are several issues about this idea. First of all, there is a 
prob=
lem with the coordinates. We had a discussion with David about 
them, and I=
 agree that I should just use the range of [-1 .. 1] for my 
substrate spac=
e. But the objects grow. So I have to either leave my 
substrate to [-infin=
ite .. +infinite] or shrink the object every time 
it gets larger. Both doe=
sn't work well, as too many garbage blobs 
appear (is it normal?), so I am =
trying to find out an alternative. One 
is that instead of inputting coordi=
nates to the CPPN, only time can be 
used as input and possibly other infor=
mation. I am thinking about this 
one in particular:

Consider this situati=
on, you are about to build something with the 
sticky cubes. You start mini=
mally and incrementally add structure. It 
is an iterative process, in whic=
h you first look at the intermediate 
construction, then *decide* what is m=
issing and place the missing 
part. Then repeat this again until you run ou=
t of cubes. Like in NEAT, 
but there is nothing else in common. I know that=
 it looks like a 
process of exploration, but consider this.. You don't kno=
w how to 
build make the final phenotype, but have a clear knowledge of the=
 
exact *path* to building it, the sense where things belong as you 
build =
it? My idea is, that every future state of the object can be 
viewed as a f=
unction of time and the current state of the object. 
Kinda confusing, isn'=
t it? 

OK let's say that an object A turns into an object B after addition=
 of 
one structural component, which requires 1 time step. Then B =3D f(A).=
 
Here is how you will produce the next object C: C =3D f(B). Then D =3D 
f=
(C). And so on.. 

So the CPPN can take the role of that function f(x). The=
 same CPPN can 
be re-queried over and over again in time, producing a fina=
l phenotype 
that is a function of time or just all of its intermediate for=
ms 
before. The challenge is how to input the object's state in a 
meaningf=
ul manner. Because the CPPN takes coordinate frames as inputs 
and outputs =
point intensity, how a whole object can be input into it? 
Or is that a CPP=
N at all? Is that just a form of recurrence without 
future? I don't know. =


But really, when you look at a sequence of photos of developing embryo 
,=
 you actually see something remarkably similar to complexifying 
evolution =
of CPPNs. But instead of a genetic lineage through 
crossovers and mutation=
s, this is one single phenotype developing from 
a single cell to a mature =
form. I believe that CPPNs and even just 
regular ANNs can abstract the tra=
nsitions from one object state to 
another very compactly. Because it is on=
ly adding structure, the 
phenotype increases in complexity over time even =
without having to 
complexify the CPPN itself. It only has to see what it d=
id so far and 
decide what to do next. It is a hypothetical idea, I haven't=
 even 
tried to implement such a thing, I actually just talk about it, ther=
e 
are many challenges, perhaps it is totally stupid, but I believe that 
i=
t may be a path to an incredible AE capable of creating highly 
complex phe=
notypes from very compact genomes. What do you think about 
it? 

Peter C

=
--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Kenneth Stanley" <kstanley@...> wrote:
>
> Pe=
ter, you make a good point that there is a challenge in 
interpreting
> arb=
itrary CPPN patterns as distinct physical objects.  I think ideas
> like yo=
urs are indeed important to explore to potentially address 
the
> issue, an=
d I found your shape-evolving novelty search program along
> those lines ve=
ry interesting.  Since you have most experience with 
the
> idea, I am curi=
ous, do you get the sense after playing with it a lot
> that the patterns t=
hat come out are indeed sufficiently diverse and
> regular to potentially r=
epresent animal morphologies?  Or does there
> seem to be anything lacking =
from the output of such systems?
> 
> ken
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com,=
 "petar_chervenski" <petar_chervenski@>
> wrote:
> >
> > I'd like to point =
out that CPPNs can be combined effectively with 
> > cellular growth models=
. Because the cells need the answer to the 
> > question "Who am I?", the C=
PPN can provide that info without any 
> > interaction between cells. It ca=
n also provide instructions about, 
for 
> > example "Should I divide or no=
t? Should I change my type?". 
> > While it seems like an overkill, because=
 CPPNs already abstract 
this 
> > away without having to introduce time fo=
r development, the 
patterns 
> > generated are hard to interpret as distin=
ct physical objects. 
> > Especially in cases of repeating patterns. But ob=
jects generated 
with 
> > cellular growth instructed by CPPNs produce only=
 a single object, 
all 
> > with its distinct parts and regularities. And n=
ot ripped apart 
with 
> > artifacts as it would be after converting it fro=
m a CPPN snapshot 
> > image. One might say that such objects can still be =
infinte in 
size, 
> > but it is easy to put a limitation on the number of =
cells or cell 
> > divisions. It is also possible to make the limit dynamic=
, more 
complex 
> > CPPNs producing phenotypes with more cells.
> > 
> > P=
eter
> >

ote:
> > >
> > > Alexandre, thank you for bringing up reaction-diffusion sy=
stems.

> > > make a good point- my statement was too broad, in pa=
rt because
> > > "cellular growth model" is a fairly ambiguous term that ca=
n
> > > potentially refer to many types of systems.  
> > > 
> > > Just to =
clarify my statement, I was responding the line of 
> > discussion
> > > wi=
th Peter about encodings that actually create distinct bodily 
> > shapes
>=
 > > that are self-contained and have clear structural boundaries 
(which
>=
 > > reaction-diffusion systems tend not to produce; rather they 
produce
>=
 > > wallpaper-like patterns).  Often when growth-based models are 
used 
>=
 > to
> > > define actual bodies with distinct borders, they are studied in=
 
the
> > > context of blobs with a particular focus on how the blob knows =

when 
> > to
> > > stop growing so that a border shape can be created.  Th=
at kind 
of
> > > systems goes along with the "skin" issue that we were 
di=
scussing.
> > > 
> > > Nevertheless, the field is quite broad and there are=
 many 
possible
> > > interesting examples of such systems.  If I could rev=
isit my
> > > statement, I would reword it such as to avoid implying any 
s=
weeping
> > > generalization.
> > > 
> > > ken
> > >

ithout

iffusion systems as a cellular
